transcription.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
OK, so this is the standardization panel.
We have a bunch of brilliant minds up here, Gavin Wood,
Nikolai, Fabian, Vitalik, and Christian.
So the point in this panel is to talk about current standards,
potential issues that we might see might happen.
How can we as a community resolve some of these issues?
And how can we go forward to maybe implement perhaps
a process or something like that?
So I think to start off with, I think
it would be great to--
there are certain standards that have already
been defined that people are using and want to use,
such as the token standards, rich G standards, and so forth.
In your area, which are the ones that you currently
feel the most passionate about?
And what are your thoughts on that particular standard
and going forward?
We ever want to start, Christian?
Yeah, so I think for me it's probably tokens.
So in the Transactive Grid Energy Trading Program project,
right now we have our own custom way
of tokenizing energy credits, renewable energy credits.
And we want to move towards a standard token solution
so that it can be integrated with markets, such as etherics,
et cetera.
And so this is--
for that reason, very important.
I'm also using registries in various dabs.
But I think there it's often more straightforward.
And there might be less need for interoperability
if you have a very targeted system.
So I think for me, tokens, stuff.
Yeah, tokens and registries, I think,
probably are the two biggest categories.
And with registries, there are different types of them.
So there are some registries that are specifically
kind of targeted to particular types of metadata.
And then there's other things which are basically
named registries.
And they have a lot of different requirements,
though in some cases, kind of partially or entirely
the same interface.
Aside from those two, the third category
would be different kinds of financial contracts, exchanges,
even like purchase offers.
I want to buy X units of A for Y units of B.
So for me, it would be like proxy contracts.
Contracts where actually would hold your ether
and send it along, but maybe do something with it.
Maybe send our chairs to other proxies
or some kind of voting system based on whatever you pass through.
This would be interesting to me.
And also tokens as well, because we
need to integrate it into wallet or we did already.
And we want to obviously support as many tokens as possible.
Can you elaborate more on the proxy contracts?
I mean, the current wallet, for example, is a proxy contract.
But ideally, you should be, for example,
if the wallet you have a multi-sick on ether,
ideally you can have a multi-sick on everything,
like even a multi-sick on sending your custom tokens or whatever.
So you basically can use these proxies for whatever
you want to do with any other contract on the network.
OK.
Yeah, so I work on Maker and obviously we're
most interested in the token standard also.
And I guess my role on this panel is pretty much just going to be,
I think it's too early in nothing.
Seems like a satisfying solution yet, although I
don't have anything better.
So--
So I think identity, in some sense,
is something worth considering deeply in how
we can try and make all of the different pieces
of infrastructure fit well together while dealing
with actual individuals.
So things that are going to fold into this, like reputation,
potentially stuff to do with the outside world.
My email address, my website, and so on.
This is, in some sense, already addressed
with the notion of like this 160-bit address scheme
that we have.
But I think it's worth considering a bit deeper
and how this might feed back into things like avatars
that go across the various applications
within the Ethereum and sort of web
three at large ecosystem.
And I also note that the other thing--
we tend to think about standards as something
that they tend to be kind of opt in.
And we need standards in order to have interoperability,
right?
Different applications implement the same standard
so that they can operate with each other.
But actually, one of the great things about Ethereum
is that this is a fundamentally programmatic
infrastructure.
So we have the notion of objects existing within the system.
And these kind of already enforce standards
because they have an API.
And if you want to interact with this object that sits
at the center of some system that you do want to operate with,
then you just use the API.
And the API is a standard.
It's already there.
And there's no real prejudice because, assuming
that it's been implemented in some reasonably fair way
and you can check because there's a code there,
then we can already kind of pre-agree to the standard.
It's like if someone makes a token that
doesn't conform to the normal standards,
then maybe EtherX, a decentralized exchange,
wouldn't then be able to use those tokens.
But considering that the code is open source,
you can just clone EtherX and make an exchange for your standard
as well.
So it's great in that manner.
The topic of identity--
I want to come back to that.
I think it's an important one because as far as I know,
it hasn't been--
we haven't specified anything yet in what--
like how it should work and how the ideal version of it
should work.
The Christian yesterday explained more about U-port work.
What's the idea or design goal of that?
Is it sort of the idea that you keep your identity
in the browser and then you move it
between certain depths?
What about sort of examples where you have a phone client
or you have a web browser client or something like MetaMask
or something like-- what do you think is the most ideal way
to swap identities through different interfaces?
Yeah.
So this is, of course, a big question.
And the notion of using the same identity
on multiple devices that ultimately comes down
to key management, which is--
might be one of the greatest challenges of this whole endeavor,
how to have key management with a good UX.
Yeah, identity is, of course, very important.
And I'm glad you brought it up.
An interesting thing there is--
so when I think about identity, I
describe the kind of general outline in my talk.
And the key management issue is very important.
So I think we have to have a system of identity
where even if you lose your private key,
you don't lose your identity.
So then we come into the fact that in the current system,
contracts always interact with keys.
So you have access control in the form of if message.center
equals this address, then do this, otherwise do something else.
And that works in the context of identity
because you can have a lookup that goes from key to identity.
But it's an interesting thing to think about if we should
think about an access control system that works on the level
of identities rather than keys.
So in my mind, an identity is kind of a cryptographic identifier.
So maybe a 32 byte hash or something.
And then the contract could say, OK, I'm getting this message.
Then I look up.
If it's-- maybe it's just a key, then do this.
If I do a lookup and see, oh, this is actually an identity,
then I can have access control on the level of that identity.
And so then you can keep using these contracts,
even if you rotate your keys for your identity.
So that's something to think about.
And that, of course, if we want to go down a path like that,
it requires standardization in how we construct these contracts.
Yeah, it does paint a potential issue
that if a lot of the current apps are going to use the normal
account system and not more, say, identity system
that you won't be able to upgrade all the previous
applications to optionally slot into an identity,
but more flexible identity system.
That's one of the things we need to figure out.
Any other comments on that issue?
In general, I think that 20 byte address
are pretty wonderful identity standards themselves,
just because the sort of really important property
that they have is how they're good at completely separating
the concept of identity to the concept of how you do access
control for the identity.
And even, you know, potentially what things like registries,
how you provide metadata or assortations
about that identity.
So in general, I do think that access control is a problem
and figuring out how to switch keys around is a problem.
But all of those things--
it's important to kind of neatly separate all
of those problems so that all of those problems can
sort of hit-- at least from the point of view of applications
hit in behind one single account.
And then people can basically use whatever solutions they
want because, in theory, people have the incentive
to protect their own security and they'll
go with what's most comfortable for them.
I think that's where proxy contracts can become useful
in that regard where you essentially--
you navigate your interaction with the rest of the ecosystem
through a personal proxy contract that's
your sort of forwarder to the rest.
Right?
Yeah.
And this could be tied into any type of identity system,
potentially, so that the proxy contract then
would become the canonical--
I mean, the address of the proxy contracts
becomes the canonical identifier for you.
And then you do all your interactions through that.
But you can have multi-sig access through that
and do key rotation for access to the proxy contract,
et cetera.
So that might be a good solution.
You can go--
If the EVM can practically be expressive enough,
especially in terms of cryptography,
I think we can go very far with proxy contracts.
Like one really far out thing is if you look at something
like the Estonian digital ID standard,
then someone with an Estonian digital ID
should is theoretically able to create digital signatures
with that, and you could even have a proxy contract
and verify those.
Same.
I agree that proxy contracts work very well.
Like the address scheme is super general.
And it pretty much solves a problem like you described.
But another approach you could do is basically--
the two keys are the same identity
if they both say that about each other.
So you have one contract where everyone just comes
and like, I guess, wires up their cluster of keys,
and also a contract if you can force it to do a particular call.
It's the same thing.
And then your cluster has one canonical address,
which you use when you check the sender,
you look up the canonical address
and then see if that's authorized.
And then people can make up whatever--
they can even merge identities if you want to.
I have two identities, but then I
want to combine the reputation or something,
then I can link them together and now they're one.
Yeah, that's right.
So I think one of the--
we've heard a lot about tokens through the past few days.
It's definitely one of the more pertinent things
to think about.
And I think as a community, we've come
to very close to defining a pretty good decent standard that's
not ambiguous and people can understand.
I think the next big one would most likely be registries.
It's good that a lot of people are going to want to use
and going to think about.
I know there has been talk about questioning
where should metadata live.
It should be in the contracts themselves.
Or should it be in registries?
Gavin, I think you have opinions on that you want to share.
Sure.
Yeah, so this is a question concerning whether, given
a contract that does some particular thing,
let's assume it's a token contract that's
recording the balances of various identities,
should the contract itself contain information regarding
itself?
Or should that information be placed elsewhere on the system,
potentially in some other contract
whose rezondetras, so to speak, is purely
to retain information concerning, for example,
token contracts.
These are the two sort of options.
It's my opinion that because we live-- because we have this system--
so normally, I would place the information
in with the contract that it actually refers to.
This is mainly because in the real world,
we have siloed servers that actually have system admins
that can actually corrupt data.
And the two sort of systems can become disjoint.
But within Ethereum, of course, we don't have these problems.
And we can actually have nice isolation of use cases
without having to have the sort of real world problems
that isolation brings, such as the fact
it's stored on a different computer, potentially
with a different ISP, potentially it's
going to go down at different times and all the rest of it.
So in this instance, I would actually
prefer to have a nice contract that actually
it's rezondetrated, simply to store metadata about other contracts.
And then allow the coin contracts and all the rest
of the other token contracts, et cetera,
to do their thing, which is to say,
maintain the balances of their users.
Can you explain more what types of metadata
you're talking about, because that can mean so much?
Sure.
So specifically data concerning the contract itself,
rather than containing the data that the contract cares about.
So in this case, the data would be things
like what's the name of the contract?
Maybe there's-- typically in real programming,
we consider them like static members,
stuff that doesn't actually change with the state.
It's just to do with the actual object itself.
Yeah, in your opinion, so that--
The idea is basically names and the token symbol
or how much decimal the blazes one token has.
And I think it's definitely a valid approach.
But I could also imagine that a lot of people
may want to have tokens which are not listed in any kind of registry.
And as well as-- I see this as a like,
growing from simple things, from what we can do right now,
what we can add for example to the wallet right now in an easy way,
and what ideally we want to have at some point in the future.
At some point in the future, we probably have like missed many dabs
which allow you to look at these registries,
to modify these registries, to have all kind of search functionality.
And then it's very useful to have these registries
and maybe even exit all through this.
But in the current state, I see it more like a lean approach,
like putting the things where they are right now easy accessible
and easy to understand because it's also from the other developers
who use these contracts, who want to understand them,
they have to know that they have to look in this and this in this places.
Or maybe there's two different coin registries or three or so.
If they just like right now have it in the place
where they're actually expecting it to be, it's easier.
And it's like, I think we will grow in that direction.
So we will like mature over time.
And this also brings me to the point of the current standards.
So I don't think we can make up a standard right now
which fits everything for the next five years or so.
It will probably be many iterations.
And I think one major point is to make sure
that we have some kind of up-creatability strategy.
So what happens if like standards change?
Maybe we can use proxies in front of others or some kind of,
like, proxies where like you can change the API of your token in a way
without changing the actual contract.
Without it, the real update of the contract,
you can still be sure it's still the same contract
just now it has a different interface.
With things like this, we can actually be rather flexible
even if we have to make changes in the future.
And one other thing towards the token is for some of the guys from Knosses
have the issue that they want to not only have one contract per token
but they have a token contract which holds multiple tokens.
And that's actually something worth thinking of
how we like have token per contract or multiple tokens per contract
and how we bring this into one standard, how we make this readable.
For example, this would require not only having a coin registry
which has like token name and address
but token name address and identifier of the token used inside.
And so I really would love to really bring the community
and come up with what use cases they have
and try to find the common standard.
And I think that's more rather a process.
Yeah, then.
- So, tell it.
- Regarding standards, it's also important to just keep in mind
that modularity fundamentally is about upgradability.
So if you knew that, you know, the way things are
is exactly the way things are going to be for every one
as well just write the whole thing in spaghetti code
because it's faster.
So, when you have questions of the form, you know,
should X be lumped into object A
or should X be lumped into object B?
One of the things to think about is, you know,
what category of those objects do you expect to be upgraded
more frequently?
What category do you expect to be created
or destroyed more frequently?
So, with tokens, for example, we're going to see,
keep on seeing new tokens being issued over time.
- You have a question of, you know,
do the existing tokens that get issued?
Are they going to, like, are, you know,
who is going to be upgrading them?
Is anyone supposed to, like, have ultimate authority over them?
How are they going to be upgraded?
Is it just going to be some religious?
Creating new proxy contracts for each new standard
might actually be a pretty decent approach.
Another question, then you have the question of, you know,
when are, when is the registry going to be upgraded?
So, for example, right now, we know that tokens have names.
We know that tokens might have, you know, decimal places.
Well, guess what?
Ether has, you know, six sub denominations and, you know,
eventually people are going to decide
that they want logos and maybe the FAD in 2017
is going to be logos that are in the form of MP4 videos.
So, the, sort of importance to figure out, you know, exactly,
whatever standard we take,
how that's going to handle those kinds of situations.
- So, I think one thing that touches both registries
and tokens is name registries.
And I think this is a quite challenging problem
because whenever you have a system
that registers human meaningful strings,
there's going to be questions about economics
because these things have value.
They have different value for different people.
You have things like name squatting,
which is a huge problem in name coin, for instance.
So, this is something that, you know,
we should be thinking very carefully about.
And I think you, Gavin, have thought about auctions
in the context of registries, et cetera.
And so, just, you know, putting it out there.
- In registries, they serve essentially two purposes,
which is providing additional information,
additional metadata, but also if there are scenarios
where you want something like a namespace
for certain things to exist.
Like, if we eventually want a system where,
like one name which has the namespace in Bitcoin
wallets, then you want that interoperability
to exist in all the Bitcoin wallets.
So, then there needs to be like a community decision
to gravitate towards a certain namespace
for certain things.
And that's probably more difficult thing
than just the fact of registering metadata.
Anyone have opinions on that?
- Yeah, well, I kind of want to go on a slide track.
Like, I think before we even start talking
about more like application level standards,
we should resolve things like,
what is the correct way to deal with VM errors?
Because in the current standard,
it's like half, you know, return value VM check,
and then the other half don't have that.
So, I'm assuming there's an exception being thrown there.
And this actually is, I think, in all the standard,
or all the proposed standards right now.
So, something like that.
And then maybe some standard design patterns
for upgradability like they were saying.
And once we get those done, I think it'll be much simpler.
Like, I think the standards will just emerge naturally.
Like, a couple of people will make some great wallets
with decent standards.
Everyone will want to be compatible with that wallet.
And there's your standard.
Like, it won't change until someone makes a better thing.
- Yeah, I really agree with this.
I really think it will evolve naturally.
Like, Twitter took on other things to run.
If somebody does something which a lot of people
like the way it's done, they will adopt it,
and it will really become the standard and with time.
So, but I really would like for now,
because we are very early in this game,
to have like more community approach,
bringing in ideas.
I mean, this can be a lengthy process,
and it can be like, like,
discussion sometimes take time,
and maybe they need somewhere in this stuck path.
But it's about like bringing ideas together.
And because so many things we can't think of even yet.
Where this is going, what all will be necessary.
So, everything will come up probably will maybe be very simplistic
from compared to what we need at some point.
- Yeah.
I think one of the things I want to point out,
I want to make on that, is the way the current standards work
is whoever edited the wiki the last time.
And I think if it would be great,
I think if we can move towards just,
it doesn't have to be very complicated.
We don't have to put up mailing lists
and like get a committee on things or whatever.
But I think it would be great if there's a sort of a stamp
of approval from various people.
That this feels like the best approach at the moment.
But we could make a discussion on Reddit
and get a lot of people involved to see what they think.
- So, actually I think a good idea would be actually using GIST,
because in GIST you can comment on the GIST,
and then it moves to a wiki.
Right now kind of like it's a little bit like a Wikipedia
edit war, kind of thing, not that much.
But yeah, definitely having places
where we can bring together examples and have these talks.
- Okay, I think the last topic before,
I think we end up 10 parts.
So I think there are probably people who have some questions.
So I think one last thing I want to touch upon is,
do we feel that there should be more like formal process
for the finding standards and maybe into the future,
not at the moment.
I think at the moment it's still sort of nebulous
and growing organically.
But you know, Bitcoin has the approval process, the books.
Is there something that currently exists
in the Ethereum community,
or is there something we need to consider more?
- Yeah, so there's quite recently,
I think it was a couple of weeks ago,
Martin set out the EIP.
- Okay, great.
And there's a wiki for it as well,
if information about it, okay, well that's great then.
- Yeah, right now this is read about the
theorem protocol updates,
but one can think of like for all kinds of things.
But right now I think it's like you say,
it's very early stage,
it's very much exploration phase.
So I would, it's a lot of things like trying things out
and see what catches on.
Maybe it's about who, I mean we can make up a standard,
if nobody follows this, that's just,
it's not written, right?
- Yeah, I definitely think the Ethereum foundation's role
should be like facilitating discussions
and all this and not defining standards,
and definitely not like creating apps,
and then you have to follow those standards,
'cause that's the official one, you know.
- Yeah, okay, there's about five minutes left,
I think we open up some questions over there.
15 minutes left, okay, well, Piper.
- So there's talk about using proxy contracts,
one of the problems with that is the message center pattern,
because you use it everywhere for authorization.
You see the app where there's like a link in change
that helps facilitate this, because proxy contracts
and message centers are very, very, very, very,
because now all of a sudden everything's coming
from some other address.
- Yeah, you want to, basically the fundamental issue here
is that the call code operator maintains
all the same state except for the sender.
So it sort of just barely doesn't satisfy the role
that we, or that intuitively it's supposed to.
- Yeah, like this is also something we have with the wallet.
The wallet currently actually uses stop contracts,
so it's cheaper to deploy,
because 120,000 gas versus a 1.2 million gas,
so we have one code base and we have the stop contracts.
They use call code and the problem is inside
the actual wallet, it is, message center
is actually the calling contract,
and not the one who actually initiated it,
or the one before, and this basically makes call code
not neutral and really like a bit destroys
this library functionality, so I really would love
to see change here.
- So one of the other things that's currently not possible,
if I understand correctly, is accessing
further down the stack of message center.
Is that an option for future EVM upgrades,
being able to actually trace your way all the way back
to transaction origin?
- Yeah, it's something that we're looking at.
The argument against it is essentially isolation.
There's a notion that the current executing frame
on the stack shouldn't really be possibly prejudiced
by previous stack frames, because it breaks
the notion of encapsulation.
- Shouldn't transaction origin be excluded
in principle, yes, but there is a slight difference
in that a transaction is different to a message.
- Other questions?
- So one of the arguments for the registry again,
skipping metadata inside contracts,
is really how does the contract we will register itself?
Because either we have to register when the contract
is launched, meaning that if you have a register
that exists after the contract has launched,
the contract can register itself,
or the contract must have some sort of way
to pass on arbitrary messages, which might add
some complexity that something like a token contract
might not necessarily have, which then gives you
have the problem of who has the right
to pass arbitrary messages.
So if a token, how would the token register itself
and who would be owner of the token
if the token has no owners?
- So there's two major categories of solution
of ways of solving this, I think.
One of them basically is to say that currencies,
or tokens have to build in some mechanism,
it doesn't have to be standardized
in order to allow some particular administrator
to keep on updating registry data if they have to.
And, or alternatively, you could just say that
the token just calls the method once and it's in it code
and then never does it again.
The other approach is this proxy contract route,
which basically means that it started off
by just having the token follow whatever the API was
at the time.
And then if a new standard comes along,
or if you want to update the registry information,
then the way you would do that is by creating a new token,
which is really just a proxy pointing back
to the first token.
And then all that that new token is is basically
the same thing as the original one,
except it has a different interface
and maybe different registry data to it.
So that's like one potential way of making things
more modular.
- I was just gonna say, if you don't know how to,
basically there's two categories,
there's like immutable contracts,
which basically you know exactly what they're supposed to do.
Ahead of time you write the code
and there's no back doors or anything.
But then like if you have even one use case
where you might need to do a proxy call,
then your contract becomes, you know,
you don't, it can do anything.
And so then it needs a governance model basically.
So the answer to that is like,
if your contract is doing arbitrary behaviors,
then yes, you need a governance thing
and that's a separate problem altogether.
- Yeah, the only thing I'd add.
If the notion that actually we're gonna say all tokens
can in principle become proxy,
have proxy sort of facades in front of them,
and this can be added for all possible,
all eventual improvements to registries,
then we've got like this order n squared issue
where you're forcing all tokens
to support all registries, whereas,
so you're gonna end up with like n squared facades, right?
Whereas if we go for the root of saying,
right, well actually tokens,
maybe it's the case that they elect to a registrar
some third party address and say actually,
we're not gonna execute arbitrary transactions in the future,
but this guy can actually update metadata on our behalf,
which massively reduces the attack surface.
And it could in principle be like a multi-party,
a multi-six sort of contract,
multi-party sort of stakeholder thing
where multiple people actually have to agree that yes,
this isn't just some dodgy troll
trying to change your name to something silly,
it's actually a reasonable metadata upgrade.
Thank you, any more questions?
- So how much do standardization and conversations today,
or how much should they be influenced
by scalability conversations tomorrow?
So with respect to sharding,
if we take some approaches to standardization
that may not make sense in a sharded future,
I'm just wondering thoughts.
- That's actually good questions,
or if you have to register,
you have to token and we take the basic metadata
of the token out of the contract to a registry
and they are in a different shard,
it would get more complicated.
- Yeah, I mean, I guess today,
exactly how the sharding is gonna work,
exactly how sort of scalability and 2.0 is gonna work,
is still very much a question of research.
We've yet to do any real modeling
on the ideas that we have,
and then of course there's still feasibility
and implementation, all the rest of it.
So I think it's still a relatively long way off,
and we probably should be focusing on real use cases today
rather than presuming potential architecture decisions
that we're gonna take in maybe one, two years time.
- I feel like it's kind of a case of premature optimization.
We have this idea that, oh, maybe in the future,
there'll be different shards,
so I make certain decisions now
that that's probably not a good approach.
And I mean, I think with any future upgrades,
I guess what they should just,
we can probably rely on future upgrade,
not directly breaking what works now.
And so, if we create stuff that works now
and make sure that works, I think that's good.
- There's always the possibility
to basically copy a contract and copy its storage.
I mean, it would be maybe a manual process,
but it will work.
So you can always basically change it, move it over.
You just have to point in, the phase is tend to be new one.
So in the worst case kind of.
- Well, it depends on what the contract contains ether
or any other assets you don't control.
- Right.
- Yeah.
- But yeah, using pointers to contract in a modular fashion,
is more than anything.
- Incidentally though, this last particular argument
is actually a very good reason why you might,
very good arguments in favor of different daps
basically creating their own sub-tilgans.
- Cool.
- Thank you.
- I think that's it for this panel.
So I wanna thank all the people.
Thank you very much.
